data: One of several inscriptions found c.1930 in Via Androne (prop. Calderaro) during building works.

Santissimae
                    
                    
                    Zosime
                    
                    del,
                    
                    
                    
                    
                    
                    XXVI et de
                    cesit XI
                    
                    Octobris
                    Amantio
                    et Albino

For my most holy wife, Zosime, strong in faith, who lived for 26 years and departed 11 days before
                    the Kalends of October, in the consulship of Amantius and Albinus (= 21 September 345 AD)

Per la mia santissima moglie, Zosime, forte nella fede, che ha vissuto per 26 anni e se ne andò 11
                    giorni prima delle calende di ottobre, sotto il consolato di Amantius e Albino (21 settembre 345
                    d.C.).

This is one of relatively few Christian epitaphs in Latin from Catania. The name Zosime is a common
                    Greek one, found several times in eastern Sicily. Giving a date by referring to the consuls in
                    office during that year reflects standard Roman dating practice, but giving the precise date of
                    death in a funerary inscription is a distinctive feature of Christian funerary epigraphy, and this
                    is one of the earliest Sicilian examples to use a consular date. The misspelling of vixit as bixsit
                    reflects a common confusion of ‘B’ and ‘V’ (due to a merging of the sound represented by each letter
                    in Latin). This is more common in southern than northern Italy, and in this case may well represent
                    the influence of Greek (where use of β for a Latin V is commonplace; see no.24).

l.2 coniugi | l.3 q | quae | vixit

Apparatus criticus

English translation

For my most holy wife, Zosime, strong in faith, who lived for 26 years and departed 11 days before the Kalends of October, in the consulship of Amantius and Albinus (= 21 September 345 AD)

Italian translation

Per la mia santissima moglie, Zosime, forte nella fede, che ha vissuto per 26 anni e se ne andò 11 giorni prima delle calende di ottobre, sotto il consolato di Amantius e Albino (21 settembre 345 d.C.).

commentary

This is one of relatively few Christian epitaphs in Latin from Catania. The name Zosime is a common Greek one, found several times in eastern Sicily. Giving a date by referring to the consuls in office during that year reflects standard Roman dating practice, but giving the precise date of death in a funerary inscription is a distinctive feature of Christian funerary epigraphy, and this is one of the earliest Sicilian examples to use a consular date. The misspelling of vixit as bixsit reflects a common confusion of ‘B’ and ‘V’ (due to a merging of the sound represented by each letter in Latin). This is more common in southern than northern Italy, and in this case may well represent the influence of Greek (where use of β for a Latin V is commonplace; see no.24).

English translation

For my most holy wife, Zosime, strong in faith, who lived for 26 years and departed 11 days before the Kalends of October, in the consulship of Amantius and Albinus (= 21 September 345 AD)

Italian translation

Per la mia santissima moglie, Zosime, forte nella fede, che ha vissuto per 26 anni e se ne andò 11 giorni prima delle calende di ottobre, sotto il consolato di Amantius e Albino (21 settembre 345 d.C.).

commentary

This is one of relatively few Christian epitaphs in Latin from Catania. The name Zosime is a common Greek one, found several times in eastern Sicily. Giving a date by referring to the consuls in office during that year reflects standard Roman dating practice, but giving the precise date of death in a funerary inscription is a distinctive feature of Christian funerary epigraphy, and this is one of the earliest Sicilian examples to use a consular date. The misspelling of vixit as bixsit reflects a common confusion of ‘B’ and ‘V’ (due to a merging of the sound represented by each letter in Latin). This is more common in southern than northern Italy, and in this case may well represent the influence of Greek (where use of β for a Latin V is commonplace; see no.24).
